Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 07:39PM Shelly1953 wrote: I know it's a hard decision, but I must agree that you need to do anything and everything to fight this awful disease.  On that note, I was on Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin (x 6) and fought neuropathy by freezing small plastic bottle (8 oz water) and holding them off and on in my hands and different bottles rolling off and on with my feet.  I started after the 2nd treatment when my hands were tingling.  By using the frozen bottles I didn't and still don't have any problems with feet or hands.  In fact the nurses kept my bottles to help other patients. Good Luck with your decision.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 12:10PM Shelly1953 wrote: I'm ILC also (see my dx).  I'm not trying to sway an opinion, just tell you mine.  I did not want chemo, cried when I found out I was going to have it.  Had a rough time with it.  But you know what?  When I was sick with each chemo I felt the chemo was REALLY working.  Now that chemo is done (TCH x 6) on April 8th.  I'm so glad I did it.  ILC takes a long time to grow and tricky to find.  I felt if anything was starting in the other breast, the chemo would zap it.  I wanted to do everything possible so I don't have to do this again!  Still having treatments every 3 weeks- herceptin.  Started Tomoxifen a couple of days ago.  My feeling is if I get cancer again (heaven forbid) I want to know it's not anything I DIDN'T do to fight it. This is just my outlook.  You have to do what's right for you and your wife. Good Luck, Shelly

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2010 12:20PM Shelly1953 wrote: Nikia, I had a masectomy last year with the start of reconstruction at the same time.  Hurt Iike a @#%#.  Couldn't get up off chair by myself for a week, at least.   If you have the reconstruction, make sure to get valium.  For some reason it helps with the muscle spasms.  Made a huge difference.  All Doctors like to minimize the pain or trauma of any procedure.  I guess they figure that we won't have anything done if they said "Yeah, it will hurt like crazy!"  I agree with getting some anti-anxiety meds.  No matter how well you think you are doing this is traumatic!. As for Dr. saying low tolerence.  Bullsh*t.  You had a part of your body removed.  It's not like having a gall bladder, etc. removed because something was wrong that you felt...you felt fine before the op.  So you are going from no pain to alot of pain.  Take the pain meds you were given and take it easy.  It was an operation after all.  AND it sounds like you might be doing too much "I get out quite a bit"  Again, take it easy.  Schedule reconstruction when YOU want it. Good Luck, Shelly

Posts.Content: May 31, 2010 11:17PM Shelly1953 wrote: I was on a different mix of chemo but I too had a lot of problems with chemo.  Here's some things that might help: 1.  Take a probiotic.  Levaquin can REALLY mess up your gastro track.  Plus, chemo destroys the good bacteria in your intestines so probiotics will replenish.  Go to health food store and tell them it's to help you with your treatments and they will give you the proper dose.  It needs to be strong so don't buy at grocery store or drug store. 2.  Nausea:  There is a patch called Sancusco that you put on the day before chemo and lasts a week.  The doctor was able to get me free patches because my insurance wouldn't pay for it.  Helped alot!  Plus you take your other anti-nausea meds with it. 3.  Ativan: is supposed to help with nausea plus help keep you calm.  Very small dose but it helps.  Plus the seritonin in your brain that helps keep you happy/calm is destroyed with chemo so don't be afraid to ask for help.  I take a generic for Zoloft and has made all the difference. 4.  Drink lots, and I mean lots of liquids!!!  I couldn't stand water without a little lemon in it. But couldn't always drink it.  Water can cause nausea!  Get gatorade light or pedialyte to help keep your electrolites in balance.  I could mix water with any of the Crystal lights and that would work.  Also, coca cola (regular) will help with nausea.  Take a small glass and stir the bubbles out.  Sip slowly.  This got me through all the days I was reacting to the chemo.  But, don't drink just the coke, you need liquids without caffeine.  Liquids will also wash the chemo out of your system faster and help if you get the foggy/dizzy feeling. 5.  Eat small amounts of food every few hours instead of regular size meal.  This will also help with the vomiting.  Some people absolutely lived on popsicles.  Can try that. 6.  Most importantly, ASK FOR HELP and be insistant.  I kept telling my doctor and nurses that I was prone to panic attacks and had to go into deep depression before anyone would do something about it.  I actually quit chemo.  Was crying all the time and staying in bed.  Finally got Zoloft and decided that I HAD to do this.  Finished the four chemos that I had left.  Wasn't a walk in the park, but the above things helped.   When you get low remember to say this is killing the cancer so I can live!  Don't be a "victim" like I was at first, be a fighter.  Say to yourself "I am doing this.  I'm going to get through this and kick cancer's a$$!  Not the other way around.  You can do this!!!!! Sorry this is so long, but I hope it helps.  Hugs, Shelly
